facts.text: A licence for the supply of electric energy in the town of Gaya was obtained by one Khandelwal in the year 1928 under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

anchor.surface_text: A licence of or the supply of electric energy in the town of Gaya was obtained by one Khandelwal in the year 1928 under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

facts.text: The licence was transferred to the Gaya Electric Supply Co. Ltd. in 1932 with the required sanction of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: With the required sanction of the Government the licence was transferred to the companypany in 1932.

facts.text: The licence was revoked by the Government by a notification dated 23rd June, 1949, with effect from 9th July, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated 23rd June, 1949, the licence was revoked by the Government with effect from 9th July, 1949.

facts.text: The company filed suit No. 58 of 1949 against the State for a declaration that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the companypany filed a suit against the State for a declaration that the revocation of the licence was arbitrary, mala fide and ultra vires.

facts.text: During the pendency of suit No. 58 of 1949, negotiations started between the company and the State, leading to a deed of agreement on 28th October, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit negotiations started between the companypany and the State for a settlement of the dispute and ultimately on 28th October, 1949, a deed of agreement was arrived at between them.

facts.text: The agreement provided that the company would withdraw suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: That the companypany would withdraw the suit No. 58 of 1949 unconditionally on 25th October, 1949.

facts.text: The State of Bihar would make an advance payment of rupees five lakhs to the company within three days of the withdrawal of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: That within three days of the withdrawal of ,the suit the State of Bihar would make an advance payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany,

facts.text: The company would hand over possession of the undertaking to an authorized officer of the Government simultaneously with the advance payment.

anchor.surface_text: and, simultaneously the companypany would formally hand over the possession of the undertaking to an authorized officer of the Government.

facts.text: Both parties would make their respective valuations within three months of taking over the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: That both parties will make their respective valuations within three months of talking over the undertaking

facts.text: Any balance due to the company as per Government valuation would be paid, or excess refunded.

anchor.surface_text: and any balance of money found due to the companypany as per Government valuation will be paid to the companypany and in case of overpayment the excess paid to the companypany

facts.text: Any difference or dispute over the payment of the balance after valuation to be submitted to sole arbitration of a high government officer of rank equal to or higher than a Divisional Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: That in the case of any difference or dispute between,the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the-sole arbitration of a single arbitrator who should be a high government officer

facts.text: The arbitration clause is contained in a letter dated 13th October, 1949, substantially accepted by the company in its letter dated 17th October, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration clause is companytained in a letter dated 13th October, 1949, and was substantially accepted by the companypany in its letter dated 17th October, 1949.

facts.text: The respondent (State) took over the undertaking on 28th October, 1949, and made a payment of rupees five lakhs to the company.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the agreement the respondent took over the undertaking on 28th October, 1949, and also made a payment of rupees five lakhs to the companypany.

facts.text: On 19th January, 1950, the company sent a statement of valuation of the assets amounting to Rs. 22,06,072 to the Chief Electrical Engineer, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th January, 1950, the companypany sent a statement of valuation of the assets amounting to RS. 22,06,072, to the Chief Electrical Engineer, Bihar.

facts.text: On 6th April, 1950, the Chief Electrical Engineer intimated that the valuation amounted to Rs. 6,56,221.

anchor.surface_text: On 6th April, 1950, the Chief Electrical Engineer intimated that the valuation amounted to Rs. 6,56,221.

facts.text: The State Government intimated appointment of Mr. M. S. Rao, C.S., as sole arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: the State Government intimated to the companypany that as difference and dispute had arisen relating to valuation, Mr. M. S. Rao, C.S. -was being appointed as sole arbitrator to decide the dispute.

facts.text: The company instituted Title Suit No. 47 of 1950 on 28th September, 1950, after notice under section 80 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th September, 1950, the companypany instituted the suit, the subject-matter the application for stay, after necessary numberice under section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: In the plaint, the company alleged that the State failed to make valuation or payment by 15th March, 1950, committed breach, company rescinded agreement and forfeited five lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it was alleged ,that as the State Government had failed and neglected to make its valuation or to make payment to the companypany by -the 15th March, 1950, it companymitted a breach of the agreement and by reason of this breach the companypany had rescinded the agreement and had forfeited the sum of five lakhs

facts.text: The State filed application under section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act on 9th October, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th October, 1950, the State Government filed the present appli- cation under section 34, of the Indian Arbitration Act.

facts.text: The Additional Sub-Judge Second at Gaya dismissed the stay application by order dated 18th December, 1950, in Title Suit No. 47 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The subordinate judge held that the suit was numberin respect of any matter agreed to be referred, and that the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to stay the proceedings. In the result the stay application was dismissed.

facts.text: The State appealed to the High Court of Patna in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951, which allowed the appeal by order dated 30th March, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Order and Decree dated the 30th March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Patna  Ramaswami and Rai JJ.  in Miscellaneous Appeal No. 19 of 1951 arising out of the Order dated the 18th December, 1950,

facts.text: This Court granted special leave to appeal under Article 136 by order dated 22nd May, 1951, in Civil Appeal No. 175 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: By an order of this companyrt dated 22nd May, 1951, the companypany was granted special leave under article 136 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: The company prayed for declaration that the electrical undertaking belonged to them, damages, appointment of receiver and injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany prayed inter alia for the reliefs of declaration that the, electrical undertaking belonged to them, for damages, for appointment of receiver and for injunction.

facts.text: The State alleged the company instituted the suit with dishonest and mala fide motive to avoid arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated therein that the companypany had with a, dishonest and mala fide motive and with a view to avoid the decision of the matter in dispute in arbitration instituted the suit on incorrect and false allegations.

arguments.claim: Answer to whether dispute falls within arbitration clause depends on (a) what is the dispute, and (b) what disputes the arbitration clause covers (citing Heyman v Darwins Ltd)

arguments.claim: If arbitration agreement broad and comprehensive embracing disputes in respect of agreement, avoidance dispute referable if arises from terms; but if reasons dehors contract, cannot resort to clause

anchor.surface_text: If the arbitration agreement is broad and companyprehensive and embraces any dispute between the parties in respect of the agreement, or in respect of any provision in the agreement, or in respect of anything arising out of it, and one of the parties seeks to avoid the companytract, the dispute is referable to arbitration if the avoidance of the companytract arises out of the terms of the companytract itself.

arguments.claim: Arbitration clause must be considered according to its language and circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The arbitration clause is a written submission agreed to by the parties in a companytract and like -every written submission to arbitration must be companysidered according to its language and in the light of the circumstances in which it is made.

arguments.claim: Under s.34, court function limited: only decide if claim comes within submission to arbitration, not merits (good/bad/frivolous)

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs companytention in the suit cannot be gone into by that companyrt exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. arguments.claim: High Court thought clause broad covering all disputes out of agreement; erred, reliance on Harinagar Sugar Mills (broad clause) and Associated Livestock Farm (broad clause) irrelevant

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges in the High Court seem to have thought that the arbitration clause here had been drafted broadly and that all disputes arising out of or in respect of the agreements were referable to arbitration. Their reliance on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.

holdings.text: The legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

anchor.surface_text: From the language of the section it is quite clear that the legal proceeding which is sought to be stayed must be in respect of a matter which the parties have agreed to refer and which comes within the ambit of the arbitration agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Section 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act requiring proceedings to concern a referred matter within arbitration scope; court bound to refuse stay if outside.

holdings.text: Where a suit is commenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission to arbitration, the court is bound to refuse a stay under Section 34.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, a suit is commenced as to a matter which lies outside the submission, the court is bound to refuse a stay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory mandate under s.34; if not within agreed reference, no discretion to stay.

holdings.text: Whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause depends on (a) what the dispute is, and (b) what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Simon L.C. in Heyman v. Darwins Ltd. the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following House of Lords precedent in Heyman v Darwins Ltd to frame test for scope.

holdings.text: The present dispute concerns the government's breach of contract by failing to value and pay within time (time being of the essence), leading to rescission of the agreement and forfeiture of advance payment.

anchor.surface_text: Now as regards the first question, viz., what is the present dispute about, the answer is to be gathered from paragraphs 14 to 17 of the plaint. It is averred therein that the Government of Bihar committed breach of the agreement and failed to make any, valuation of the undertaking or pay the balance of the compensation money,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gathered from plaint paras 14-17; no claim for valuation or payment, but for rescission and breach.

holdings.text: The arbitration clause covers only differences or disputes over the payment of the balance found due after valuation, conferring jurisdiction solely on valuation pure and simple.

anchor.surface_text: The clause here is that if any difference or dispute arises between the parties over the payment of the balance which may be found due after valuation such dispute shall be submitted to the sole arbitration of a single arbitrator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of clause language; scheme of agreement limits to post-valuation balance disputes including 20% compensation.

holdings.text: The suit's claims on breach of contract, time being of the essence, and rescission are outside the scope of the narrow arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: Questions relating to the breach of contract or its rescission are outside the reach of this clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause does not empower arbitrator on time essence justification or breach determination; distinguished from broad clauses.

holdings.text: The arbitrator has not been conferred power to decide whether plaintiff was justified in claiming time of the essence or whether government committed breach by not valuing timely.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator has not been conferred the power by this clause to pronounce on the issue whether the plaintiff was justified in claiming that time was of the essence of the contract and whether the State Government committed a breach of the contract by not making a valuation within the time specified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow clause limits jurisdiction to valuation disputes, excluding preliminary breach/rescission issues.

holdings.text: Under Section 34, the court's function is limited to deciding whether the claim falls within the arbitration submission, not its merits (validity, frivolousness).

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. The only point in such cases to be decided is whether the claim which is brought- whether it is good, bad or indifferent comes within the submission to arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural limit on s.34 enquiry; High Court erred by deciding time stipulation issue which is suit's merit.

holdings.text: The applicant (State) was ready and willing to do all things necessary for arbitration at commencement and remains so.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of, the Indian Arbitration Act runs thus - ...and that the applicant was, at the time when the proceedings were commenced, and still remains, ready and willing to do all things necessary to the proper conduct of the arbitration, such authority may make an order staying the proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfied from facts and application, but insufficient alone as first condition fails.

holdings.text: Precedents like Harinagar Sugar Mills and Associated Livestock Farm irrelevant as they involved broad arbitration clauses covering all disputes arising out of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges in the High Court seem to have thought that the arbitration clause here had been drafted broadly and that all disputes arising out of or in respect of the agreements were referable to arbitration. Their reliance on the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished on clause wording: present clause narrow vs. broad 'any dispute arising out of contract' in those cases.

anchor.surface_text: Heyman v. Daruins Ltd  1 . the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a compantract must depend on  a  what is the dispute, and  b  what disputes the arbitration clause companyers.

precedents.cited_proposition: The answer to whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause depends on (a) what the dispute is and (b) what disputes the clause covers; if broad and comprehensive embracing disputes in respect of the agreement or arising out of it, repudiation arising from its terms is referable to arbitration, but not if for reasons dehors the contract.
precedents.cited_holding: In the words of Viscount Simon L.C.: the answer to the question whether a dispute falls within an arbitration clause in a contract must depend on a what is the dispute, and b what disputes the arbitration clause covers.

anchor.surface_text: Monro v. Bognor Urban Council  1 , are material only if the question to be companysidered is whether the case made was a frivolous and vexatious one and ought to have had numberweight at all upon the question of what the plaintiffs claim in fact was and one can only find out what his claim is by looking at the plaint.

precedents.cited_proposition: In stay applications under arbitration acts, considerations of whether the claim is frivolous or vexatious are relevant only to whether to stay if frivolous, but the court must determine what the claim is from the plaint itself, without going into merits.
precedents.cited_holding: as pointed out by Banks J ... those considerations ... are material only if the question to be considered is whether the case made was a frivolous and vexatious one and ought to have had no weight at all upon the question of what the plaintiff's claim in fact was and one can only find out what his claim is by looking at the plaint.

precedents.citation: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Skoda India Ltd.   in support of the decision indicates the error. In that case the arbitration clause was drafted in a companyprehensive language and stated that a dispute arising out of the agreement had to be referred to arbitration.

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Skoda India Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Disputes arising out of the agreement are referable to arbitration where the clause is comprehensively worded to that effect.

precedents.citation: Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd.  3

anchor.surface_text: Governor- General in Council v. Associated Livestock Farm Ltd.  3  also shows that they were under the same erroneous impression. In this case the arbitration clause was in these terms -

precedents.case_name: Governor-General in Council v Associated Livestock Farm Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Any dispute or difference arising out of the contract shall be referred to the arbitration of the officer sanctioning the contract whose decision shall be final and binding.
precedents.cited_holding: Arbitration clause: Any dispute or difference arising out of the contract shall be referred to the arbitration of the officer sanctioning the contract whose decision shall be final and binding.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of it is arbitration clause is a very narrow one. It only confers jurisdiction on the arbitrator on the question of valuation of the undertaking pure and simple and does not say that all disputes arising out of the agreement or in respect of it will be decided by arbitration.

The validity of the plaintiffs contention in the suit cannot be gone into by that court exercising jurisdiction under this section as its function is a very limited one. The only point in such cases to be decided is whether the claim which is brought- whether it is good, bad or indifferent comes within the submission to arbitration.
